# This Python 3 environment comes with many helpful analytics libraries installed
# It is defined by the kaggle/python Docker image: https://github.com/kaggle/docker-python
# For example, here's several helpful packages to load
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
import plotly.graph_objects as go
from plotly.offline import init_notebook_mode,iplot
init_notebook_mode(connected=True)
import cufflinks as cf
cf.go_offline(True)
import plotly.express as px

import numpy as np # linear algebra
import pandas as pd # data processing, CSV file I/O (e.g. pd.read_csv)

# Input data files are available in the read-only "../input/" directory
# For example, running this (by clicking run or pressing Shift+Enter) will list all files under the input directory

import os
for dirname, _, filenames in os.walk('/kaggle/input'):
    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

# You can write up to 20GB to the current directory (/kaggle/working/) that gets preserved as output when you create a version using "Save & Run All" 
# You can also write temporary files to /kaggle/temp/, but they won't be saved outside of the current session
source.45a85e3f:
fig=px.choropleth(data_frame=c_vac,
                          locations=c_vac['country'],
                          locationmode='country names',
                          color=c_vac['vaccines'],
                          animation_group=c_vac['vaccines'])
fig.update_layout(dict1={'title':'Covid-Vaccines'})
fig.show()
source.43683e84:
fig=px.choropleth(data_frame=c_vac,
                          locations=c_vac['country'],
                          locationmode='country names',
                          color=c_vac['total_vaccinations_per_hundred'],
                          animation_frame=c_vac['date'],
                          animation_group=c_vac['vaccines'])
fig.update_layout(dict1={'title':'Total Vaccinations per hundred'})
fig.show()
source.ada4d771:
fig = go.Figure()
for x in c_vac['country'].unique():
    fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=c_vac['date'], y=c_vac[c_vac['country']==x]['total_vaccinations_per_hundred'],
                         mode='lines+markers',
                         name=x))
fig.update_layout(dict1={'title':'Total Vaccinations Per Hundred'})
fig.show()
source.8956867d:
fig=px.choropleth(data_frame=c_vac,
                          locations=c_vac['country'],
                          locationmode='country names',
                          color=c_vac['daily_vaccinations_per_million'],
                          animation_frame=c_vac['date'],
                          animation_group=c_vac['vaccines'])
fig.update_layout(dict1={'title':'Daily Vaccinations Per Million'})
fig.show()

fig = go.Figure()

                         mode='lines+markers',

fig.update_layout(dict1={'title':'Daily Vaccinations Per Million'})

source.357439d5:
fig=px.choropleth(data_frame=c_vac,
                          locations=c_vac['country'],
                          locationmode='country names',
                          color=c_vac['people_vaccinated_per_hundred'],
                          animation_frame=c_vac['date'],
                          animation_group=c_vac['vaccines'])
fig.update_layout(dict1={'title':'People Vaccinated per hundred'})
fig.show()
source.47e041a1:
fig = go.Figure()
for x in c_vac['country'].unique():
    fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(x=c_vac['date'], y=c_vac[c_vac['country']==x]['people_vaccinated_per_hundred'],
                         mode='lines+markers',
                         name=x))
fig.update_layout(dict1={'title':'People Vaccinated Per Hundred'})

fig.show()
source.609ec437: c_vac.groupby('country')['people_vaccinated_per_hundred'].mean().sort_values()[40:].iplot(title='Top 20 countries based on people vaccinated per hundred')
source.8f504912: c_vac.groupby('country')['total_vaccinations_per_hundred'].mean().sort_values()[40:].iplot(title='Top 20 countries based on Total Vaccinations Per Hundred')
source.903661a8: c_vac.groupby('country')['daily_vaccinations_per_million'].mean().sort_values()[40:].iplot(title='Top 20 countries based on Daily Vaccinations Per Million ')
source.dec6ead2: # **Percent of Null values in each column:**
source.68503510: The features 'people_fully_vaccinated' and 'people_fully_vaccinated_per_hundred' are highly correlated to some other features. Based on calculation, these features have 78% of null values. So these columns are not taken into consideration for visualisation.
source.3fe47b9d: Based on the visualisations, 'Total vaccinations per hundred','Daily vaccinations per million' and 'People vaccinated per hundred' are the three factors, which helps to track the progress of vaccinations in the countries and helps to know the top performers in the covid vaccinations.
